013package org.apache.juneau.examples.core.html;
014
015import org.apache.juneau.examples.core.pojo.Pojo;
016import org.apache.juneau.examples.core.pojo.PojoComplex;
017import org.apache.juneau.html.HtmlSerializer;
018import org.apache.juneau.html.HtmlParser;
019
020import java.util.ArrayList;
021import java.util.HashMap;
022import java.util.List;
023
024/**
025 * Sample class which shows the complex usage of HtmlSerializer and HtmlParser.
026 *
027 * <ul class='seealso'>
028 * </ul>
029 */
030public class HtmlComplexExample {
031
032   /**
033    * Serializing PojoComplex bean into Html type
034    * and Deserialize back to PojoComplex instance type.
035    *
036    * @param args Unused.
037    * @throws Exception Unused.
038    */
039   public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
040      // Juneau provides static constants with the most commonly used configurations
041      // Get a reference to a serializer - converting POJO to flat format
042      /**
043       * Produces
044       * <table><tr><td>innerPojo</td><td><table><tr><td>name</td><td>name0</td></tr>
045       * <tr><td>id</td><td>1.0</td></tr></table></td></tr><tr><td>values</td><td><table>
046       * <tr><td>setOne</td><td><table _type="array"><tr><th>name</th><th>id</th></tr>
047       * <tr><td>name1</td><td>1.1</td></tr><tr><td>name2</td><td>1.1</td></tr>
048       * </table></td></tr><tr><td>setTwo</td><td><table _type="array"><tr><th>name
049       * </th><th>id</th></tr><tr><td>name1</td><td>1.2</td></tr><tr><td>name2</td><td>1.2
050       * </td></tr></table></td></tr></table></td></tr><tr><td>id</td><td>pojo</td></tr></table>
051       */
052      HtmlSerializer htmlSerializer = HtmlSerializer.DEFAULT;
053      // Get a reference to a parser - converts that flat format back into the POJO
054      HtmlParser htmlParser = HtmlParser.DEFAULT;
055
056      // Fill some data to a PojoComplex bean
057      HashMap<String, List<Pojo>> values = new HashMap<>();
058      ArrayList<Pojo> setOne = new ArrayList<>();
059      setOne.add(new Pojo("1.1", "name1"));
060      setOne.add(new Pojo("1.1", "name2"));
061      ArrayList<Pojo> setTwo = new ArrayList<>();
062      setTwo.add(new Pojo("1.2", "name1"));
063      setTwo.add(new Pojo("1.2", "name2"));
064      values.put("setOne", setOne);
065      values.put("setTwo", setTwo);
066      PojoComplex pojoc = new PojoComplex("pojo", new Pojo("1.0", "name0"), values);
067
068      String flat = htmlSerializer.serialize(pojoc);
069
070      // Print out the created POJO in JSON format.
071      System.out.println(flat);
072
073      PojoComplex parse = htmlParser.parse(flat, PojoComplex.class);
074
075      assert parse.getId().equals(pojoc.getId());
076      assert parse.getInnerPojo().getName().equals(pojoc.getInnerPojo().getName());
077      assert parse.getInnerPojo().getId().equals(pojoc.getInnerPojo().getId());
078
079      // The object above can be parsed thanks to the @Beanc(properties = id,name) annotation on Pojo
080      // Using this approach, you can keep your POJOs immutable, and still serialize and deserialize them.
081   }
082}
